prompt_init: You will receive a text. Your task is to create a new original text by taking inspiration from this text. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to create a new original text by taking inspiration from this text. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
initial_story:
Firefighters and police were seen outside the office of Mike Freer MP

Police are investigating a suspected arson attack at the office of North London Conservative MP Mike Freer.

A fire broke out at the rear of the North Finchley and Golders Green MP's constituency office at around 19:00 on Christmas Eve.

The Met Police confirmed it is investigating the fire.

Mr Freer told the BBC the fire happened at the rear of the premises and no one was in the building at the time of the incident.

He continued: "The police and fire brigade were on the scene in minutes and have been incredible in their response."

London Fire Brigade (LFB) confirmed the fire started in a shed outside the office before spreading to the rest of the building.

An LFB spokesperson said: "An external shed was destroyed by fire. Part of the first, second and third floors of the property were also damaged by the blaze."

In a statement, a Metropolitan Police spokesperson said: "The cause of the fire is under investigation as it is believed it may have been started deliberately. There have been no arrests."

Pictures posted on social media showed Metropolitan Police and LFB vehicles at the premises on Sunday evening.

Mr Freer has represented the North London constituency since 2010.

He is parliamentary under-secretary of state for courts and legal services, a junior role in the Ministry of Justice.

Pictures show the fire spread to an office inside the building

A blaze engulfed the office of a junior government official in North London on a sunny day in March. The London Fire Brigade arrived at the scene to find the entire building engulfed in flames, with thick black smoke billowing into the sky. The cause of the fire was quickly determined to be arson, with the perpetrator having doused the building in gasoline and set it alight. The official, who was not present at the time of the fire, later stated that he had received numerous death threats in the weeks leading up to the incident. The police are currently investigating the incident, and have not yet made any arrests. The building was completely destroyed in the fire, with nothing but charred remains left behind. The official has vowed to rebuild, stating that he will not be intimidated by those who seek to silence him.

In a dramatic twist, the official was later revealed to be the arsonist, having set the fire himself in order to cover up evidence of his own corruption. The police investigation revealed that the official had been embezzling funds from the government for years, and had become increasingly desperate to hide his tracks as the evidence mounted against him. The official was eventually arrested and charged with arson and corruption, and is currently awaiting trial.

The incident sent shockwaves through the community, with many expressing disbelief that someone in a position of trust could betray their responsibilities so completely. The official's betrayal has led to a renewed focus on accountability and transparency in government, with many calling for increased oversight and stricter penalties for those who abuse their power.

Despite the official's arrest and the damage caused by the fire, the community has come together to support those affected and to rebuild the office. The official's replacement has pledged to work tirelessly to restore the community's trust in the government, and to ensure that such a betrayal never happens again.

A blaze engulfed the office of a junior government official in North London on a sunny day in March. The London Fire Brigade arrived at the scene to find the entire building engulfed in flames, with thick black smoke billowing into the sky. The cause of the fire was quickly determined to be arson, with the perpetrator having doused the building in gasoline and set it alight. The official, who was not present at the time of the fire, later stated that he had received numerous death threats in the weeks leading up to the incident.
